Field trips were well designed and ran smoothly.
I learned a lot from field trips.
How clearly does the instructor provide explanations of conceptual material?
How responsive to student comments was the instructor?
I would give the instructor of this class an overall rating of:
I would give this course an overall rating of:
Apart from how well the course was taught, how valuable is the course to students with interests similar to yours?

narratives.question_text: Use the space below to comment on questions 1-14, if you wish
comments: Amazing opportunity
This was a very practical class. I learned about Climate Change negotiations directly from negotiators. Opinions were very diverse and it was a great learning experience.

narratives.question_text: What were the best aspects of this course?
comments: Interactions with the UN, collaboration with professor and classmates
Interviews with Climate change delegates

I thought the opportunity to interact with diplomats through face-to-face interviews was an unparalleled and valuable experience. I was able to go to NYC several times to conduct 13 interviews with these high level officials. Each one was very open and enthusiastic to speak with me, which was encouraging. The end of the semester opportunity to then present these findings at the UN was a huge honor and fantastic experience.The student-driven creation of the questionnaire was also a good learning experience, especially for those students who have never conducted semi-structured interviews.
Different format from most years - project-focused format was unique and interesting opportunity.

The best aspect of the course was the experiential learning which allowed for much deeper learning than simply engaging with reading material. The course presentation process was a very tangible way to drive home this learning.

narratives.question_text: What aspects of this course need the most improvement?
comments: Logistics coordination
More structure and better preparation for the class, especially at the beginning.
I think coordination of the class and ensuring every students meets his or her commitments to the class was the biggest challenge.
Clearer organization and objectives, better preparation for students less familiar with relevant information and processes.
While the course is somewhat free-form, there could be clearer expectations and delegation of tasks determined in the early stages of the semester.

narratives.question_text: Was the relationship between the course lectures and discussion/lab section
comments: Very effective

narratives.question_text: Discuss, if you wish, how this course fits into your overall program.  (Please feel free to describe how the course relates to your academic background.)
comments: Interest in international diplomacy

Understanding intergovernmental processes is extremely relevant to international sustainable development work. Analysing institutional factors contributing to their success or failure further deepens understanding and improves ability to navigate those institutions.

narratives.question_text: Why did you take this course?
comments: See above
Because of the possibility to learn directly from UN negotiators about Climate Change negotiations.

I took this course to learn more about the international negotiations process and how it could be improved. I also wanted to enjoy this unique experience to interview UN officials and learn from these delegates who operate "on the ground" at international meetings.
Interesting project opportunity.
I took this course in order to better refine my understanding of the UNFCCC process and what intervention points will be most effective to engage with in my professional career moving forward.

narratives.question_text: Did the knowledge/skills that you gained from the course meet your expectations ?
comments: Yes, thank you!
Yes, it was a great experience to take this class.
Yes

narratives.question_text: If yes, what were the advantages and disadvantages of the group work?
comments: Collaboration, innovation

The students in this class were all very competitive, yet many did not meet their obligations to the class. I think students became very discouraged when they couldn't secure meetings with the specific ambassadors they wanted to speak with. Even though the professor and other students offered interviewing opportunities, very few students in the class actually took advantage of this.I think students need to enter this type of class only if they are willing to be open minded and flexible. A lot of clashing personalities made class meetings sometimes very painful or onerous, due to the level of debating and arguing occurring. Some students I think achieved very little but still received the same benefits and opportunities as students who put many hours into contacting missions and obtaining interviews.Overall, this class definitely required a large time commitment, a greater one than many students anticipated. I think the division of 1 - 3 credits made this difficult for students to grasp. I would recommend that all students take this course for 3 credits and be required to attend a certain number of interviews, as there were plenty of opportunities to do so even if a student's own outreach failed. I also think those students who complete the most number of interviews should be given priority in presenting on results and a fair contribution to the final paper, rather than just arbitrarily assigning these roles.
Multiple perspectives helpful, but more so when all involved have some shared basic level of knowledge and command of the subject matter.
The group work really helped strengthen the couse, although group work near the end of the semester became somewhat strained due to high stress environments.

narratives.question_text: For students who might consider taking this course, what advice would you give them?
comments: Enjoy!!
To try and schedule interviews well in advance.
Be prepared to push hard to clarify understandings of things. Don't settle for vagueness.
